Exercise 2.3-3

Use mathematical induction to show that when n is an exact power of 2, the solution of the recurrence

T(n) = { 2, if n = 2

T(n) = { 2T(n/2) + n, if n = 2k, for k > 1

is T(n) = nlgn

In the base case, k = 1, and so n = 21. T(n) = nlgn = 2·lg(21) = 2·1 = 2.

Next we suppose this holds for any k > 1, and will show that it also holds for any k + 1:

T(n/2) + n = nlgn

2[(2k + 1/2)·lg(2k + 1/2)] + 2k + 1 = 2k + 1lg2k + 1

2{[2k + 1/2]·[lg(2k + 1/2) - lg2] + 2k + 1 = 2k + 1(k + 1)

2{[2k + 1/2]·[k + 1 - 1] + 2k + 1 = 2k + 1(k + 1)

2k + 1·k + 2k + 1 = 2k + 1(k + 1)

2k + 1(k + 1) = 2k + 1(k + 1)
